t: Job 18
Bildad
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite replied:
“When*pn will you end these speeches? Be*ld sensible, and then we can talk.
Why*ln are we regarded as cattle and*ld considered stupid in your sight?
You*ln who tear yourself to pieces in your anger, is*ld the earth to be abandoned for your sake? Or*ld must the rocks be moved from their place?
“The*pn lamp of a wicked man is snuffed out; the*ld flame of his fire stops burning.
The*ln light in his tent becomes dark; the*ld lamp beside him goes out.
The*ln vigor of his step is weakened; his*ld own schemes throw him down.
His*ln feet thrust him into a net; he*ld wanders into its mesh.
A*ln trap seizes him by the heel; a*ld snare holds him fast.
A*ln noose is hidden for him on the ground; a*ld trap lies in his path.
Terrors*ln startle him on every side and*ld dog his every step.
Calamity*ln is hungry for him; disaster*ld is ready for him when he falls.
It*ln eats away parts of his skin; death’s*ld firstborn devours his limbs.
He*ln is torn from the security of his tent and*ld marched off to the king of terrors.
Fire*ln resides in his tent; burning*ld sulfur is scattered over his dwelling.
His*ln roots dry up below and*ld his branches wither above.
The*ln memory of him perishes from the earth; he*ld has no name in the land.
He*ln is driven from light into the realm of darkness and*ld is banished from the world.
He*ln has no offspring or descendants among his people, no*ld survivor where once he lived.
People*ln of the west are appalled at his fate; those*ld of the east are seized with horror.
Surely*ln such is the dwelling of an evil man; such*ld is the place of one who does not know God.”
